title.value: Overcoming Interpretability and Accuracy Trade-off in Medical Imaging
title.justification: The title of the paper is directly mentioned at the beginning.
title.quote: Overcoming Interpretability and Accuracy Trade-off in Medical Imaging

extractions.description: The paper addresses the challenge of balancing interpretability and accuracy in medical imaging models by proposing a novel concept-based model called coop-CBM. This model aims to provide high-level concept explanations without sacrificing predictive performance.

type.justification: The paper presents experimental validation of the proposed model, coop-CBM, using dermatology and histopathology image datasets.
type.quote: We validate the performance of coop-CBM on diverse dermatology and histopathology images.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on improving models for medical imaging tasks.
name.quote: The field of medical imaging has observed tremendous advancements in recent times with the aid of computer vision algorithms, assisting radiologists and pathologists in accurately diagnosing diseases.

name.justification: A significant portion of the paper discusses improving the interpretability of deep learning models in medical imaging.
name.quote: Neural networks are considered black boxes. Deploying them into the healthcare domain poses a challenge in understanding model behavior beyond the final prediction.

name.justification: The paper introduces the concept-based model coop-CBM and discusses its advantages over traditional models.
name.quote: Concept learning models have gained popularity in explaining their own predictions while conditioning on human-understandable concepts.

name.justification: The main contribution of the paper is the proposal of the concept-based model coop-CBM, which aims to improve accuracy without sacrificing interpretability.
name.quote: To overcome this challenge we propose coop-CBM, a novel concept-based model.

is_contributed.justification: The coop-CBM model is an original contribution proposed in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: To overcome this challenge we propose coop-CBM, a novel concept-based model.

is_executed.justification: The experiments in the paper mention the validation of coop-CBM, implying its execution.
is_executed.quote: We validate the performance of coop-CBM on diverse dermatology and histopathology images.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the performance of coop-CBM with other baseline models like Concept Bottleneck Models and Concept Embedding Models.
is_compared.quote: To evaluate the performance, here, we are concerned with the final prediction accuracy, i.e. performance of pF (y|c). From Table 1, we notice our method has the most superior performance in comparison to the baselines on both TIL and DDI datasets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no referenced paper for coop-CBM since it is introduced in this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: To overcome this challenge we propose coop-CBM, a novel concept-based model.

name.justification: The TIL dataset is used in the experiments to classify cancer tumors.
name.quote: We consider two classification datasets, TIL (Saltz et al., 2018) and DDI (Daneshjou et al., 2021, 2022) to classify cancer tumors and skin diseases respectively.

referenced_paper_title.value: Spatial organization and molecular correlation of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes using deep learning on pathology images
referenced_paper_title.justification: The TIL dataset is referenced to Saltz et al., 2018 for its creation and use.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We consider two classification datasets, TIL (Saltz et al., 2018) and DDI (Daneshjou et al., 2021, 2022) to classify cancer tumors and skin diseases respectively.

name.justification: The DDI dataset is used in the experiments to classify skin diseases.
name.quote: We consider two classification datasets, TIL (Saltz et al., 2018) and DDI (Daneshjou et al., 2021, 2022) to classify cancer tumors and skin diseases respectively.

referenced_paper_title.value: Disparities in dermatology AI: Assessments using diverse clinical images
referenced_paper_title.justification: The DDI dataset is referenced to Daneshjou et al., 2021 and 2022 for its creation and use.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We consider two classification datasets, TIL (Saltz et al., 2018) and DDI (Daneshjou et al., 2021, 2022) to classify cancer tumors and skin diseases respectively.
